instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
G;day! 

Had a Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in for repair after it had been dropped. 

Fixed the drop by replacing the LCD cable, ( was pins were physically broken. 

Also replaced  <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>

Dropped off to customer, and they were happy. 


Since then they plugged in a 65W charger, which made it go sideways and panic, keep rebooting and couldn't log into user. 

Collect back off customer and can't work it out for the life of me. 

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SO_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is .5v or not present at times. 
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 12V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> is 12.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_BKL</SIGNAL> = 1.2v or less(.200 - .400 amps) 
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v

It fan spins for about 15 - 20 seconds then stops, with a little bit of a wait, it'll fan spin again shortly after.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Do you get image at least?
Check for USB activity too.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply! 

I get USB activity while the fans are spinning, but they stop, then start again shortly after, while they stop as expected, no USB. 

No image either :/

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Are you sure about USB activity?
Power light on USB device, doesn't mean activiy.
Read the forum, we explained (too) many times how to confirm it.
If you don't get image, no reason to search for backlight.

There could be classic FDMF6808N issue.
If you don't have real new FDMF6708/3030 to change them, you should try the script to disable CPU sleep states.
It is available somewhere on Internet, just search with patience.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Hey thanks so much for your reply! 

Appreciated as always! 

I have realised that this board does not boot without the sub-board attached. 

I feel silly. 

I only connected it to check for HDMI and it boots correctly. 

Assuming just makes an ass out of me :)

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
My mistakes... 


Got that one boot, then put it back together and now same thing.... :(

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk; disconnect anything, apart of DC cable.
Use onboard USB port to confirm activity.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message: Just as a reminder you need a known good battery connected for this machine to fully boot into macOS.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Everything disconnected, no USB activity, just power. 

I have has this mac boot without battery connected as well?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Dropped machine is nightmare always.
There should be broken traces, or solders.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message: In your opinion it's a rabbit hole then? Give up?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message: Inspect the board close to heatsink holes and all onboard connectors.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Thanks again, 

I have, everything looks fine. 


Is there anything that would cause this from using the 65W charger rather then the 85W charger?? 

Only reason why I'm asking is it was fine, tested completely working, up until the customer used their 65W charger. 

I think this is to much of a rabbit hole for me :) LOL

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
00163 requires 85W charger.
It will not start with 45/60W charger, unless good battery is connected.
Even with 85W charger, may not boot correctly, if no battery connected.

Customer's charger is fake one?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
It was dropped I repaired it, replaced LVDS cable and back light driver

tested and it was working fine, dropped it off, it was working fine, even chatted to the bloke for a bit, he plugged it into his charger 65W charger, and the screen flickered and macbook froze, we restarted it a few times however after logging in it would freeze shortly after and crash. 

I took it back and now we here :/ Just fan spin for 30 seconds or so then stop, all power rails present. 

No USB activity, no boot, no chime :(

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message:
Bad charger can only damage SMC, through <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> line.
If <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> doesn't isolate properly this signal.
But if machine still turned on few times after, is not from charger probably.

Screen flicker and frozen machine, can point to bad GPU.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display
threads.message: Thanks so much for your replies mate, really appreciate it!
